name: Cook, Serve, Delicious!
description: One of the few hardcore restaurant sims in existence, Cook, Serve, Delicious! is a deceptively easy game to learn but incredibly challenging to master as you progress through your career from owning a terrible zero star cafe into a five star world famous restaurant.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows Vista, 7/8/10 Memory: 2 GB RAM Graphics: 128MB Graphics card or greater Storage: 150 MB available space

reviews.review_text: This is one of the most stressful games I've ever played. And I put over 20 hours into it over a period of weeks, always coming back to it to serve another day. You are running a restaurant, but the complexity of it severely outstrips your regular diner dash style game. Almost every food has multiple recipes (there are something like 35 different hamburger combinations possible), and your menu has upwards of 20 items, of which you can serve 4-6 on any given day. Manage service, janitorial requirements and a variety of other tasks. It's hard to describe how complex and yet how engaging this game is. It is seriously stressful, especially on the later levels, but pulling off 88 orders in a row perfectly is a rush; this is really an underrated and great game.

Cook, Serve, Delicious! is a restaurant/cooking simulator where you start with a rundown little cafe and turn it into a five star restaurant all the while cooking numerous dishes, fending off robbers and flushing blocked toilets. While the game might not sound like everyone's cup of tea it combines addictive gameplay with a good progression system to make a fun gaming experience. As a huge fan of the Papa's Pizzeria games this was a must buy for me and I was not disappointed.  +Nice simplistic graphics, food and drink is well designed and the UI is nice to look at as well +Incredibly addictive, simple gameplay that keeps you coming back for more +You can take place in bets each day which require you to get a certain combo with certain foods +You are rewarded for perfect orders and penalised for bad orders which helps push you to try as hard as you can +Lots of different dishes including drinks +Most dishes have upgrades which adds a new ingredient and new recipe cards +All recipe cards have specific names +Local co-op game mode +The hotkeys for the different ingredients are for the most part intuitive, i.e. the first letter of the ingredient is the hotkey, and if you don't like them the hotkeys can be edited +Full controller support for both the Xbox 360 Controller and the Dualshock 4 Controller +Great music +There are special events in the game which you can take part in such as catering events which earn you more money  -The frequency of work orders (flushing the toilet, cleaning the dishes, taking out the trash and setting rat traps) seemed a bit too high, in particular the flushing the toilet job seemed to be very frequent even when the toilet had been upgraded -The progression on the star system is very slow and food upgrades are very expensive -Once you start unlocking more order slots (you start with four and then it increases) it becomes increasingly difficult to keep track of all of the orders you have on the go and I often pressed the wrong key and sent out an order early, breaking a combo -I had a couple of issues where I lost saves and had to replay about 2 hours worth -You can't upgrade the appearance of your restaurant apart from the automatic changes when you get a new star   Verdict: 7  A great restaurant/cooking sim that is perfect for fans of similar games but might be quite boring for most, best to pick this up on sale.  El K.

I find myself weary of the middle-aged man who orders beer at 9:30 every morning and judging the hipster snobs who decide to order salad with everything on it during rush hour. Fun and addictive little game!
pretty good game if you like crying and stress 10/10
easy to burn, hard to pasta.

'Eh its just another one of those fast pace clicking/typing games'  *3 hours later*  'I'm still playing this sh*t?!'   10/10 Good way to pass time...and positively addicting  For the Steam Fall Sale of 2016: I nominated this because why not. It's good.

What I liked:     A decent cooking game with a unique way to cook     the rhythm of cooking during rush hour    That feeling when you know the recipes by heart and fly by those orders   What You Need to Know:     This is not a simulation game, you don’t really manage a restaurant. It’s mostly on the food minigames that is the core gameplay, no prep, tweaking food prices, supply and demand.    The beginning is very slow when not during rush hour everyday. Later in the game when at 3 star your restaurant you will have very little downtime. It’s stressful and challenging but really fun.    I do hate that can’t start the order over if you made a mistake and can force you lose the perfect day bonus, which early on a lot compared to your daily income, later on in the game, it’s not really needed    I wish you the stats gave me more info like how many days I had an item on the menu, tips per food to try and maximize my profits bro    Cooking is a button mashing mechanic with each item being something different; chores are the same way (love the robbery minigame, sarcasm of course)    You can bet money to see how many perfect orders you can get in a row, everyday its randomized what items are needed on the menu    I played this using a controller, it just seems easier but mistakes can be made when using the analog sticks. ( I did try using the mouse and the arrow keys only, it's doable, but damn it's a clickfest. I don't know how keyboard is even plausible)    This game is very repetitive; your goal is to get to a 5 star restaurant. A checklist of requirements needs to be met to go up a star    They require 20 days minimum as the annoying requirement. This requirement will be the last one done and wish this wasn't a requirement. It would make the game shorter, more enjoyable, and less grindy    There are catering and iron chef style events that offer different challenges, but are few and don't happen till level 2 and 3 restaurants. Each level of star takes about 3-4 hours.    You are rewarded if you have a perfect day, sadly if you make a mistake in an order you can’t restart the order and have to take the penalty. You can just restart the day over if it was at the beginning, otherwise I would just take the hit and not get bonus( because money was never really an issue)   It might sound like the game is bad, it’s not, it’s just not great either. I wanted it to be more of a management cooking game( plus I played this after playing Overcooked which is amazing)     My Score:

Ahhh, Cook, Serve, Delicious. One of my most favourite games of all time. It has everything from keeping you adrenaline pumped when you perfect a day to making you cry in shame for messing up one single order. 10/10 would play again.

This is the only cooking game on steam that I find addictive to play because of it's hard & fast game mechanics to see how much food you can cook, I'm going to post my thoughts on what makes this game delicious (At The End Of Each Day You Might Get Positive Or Negative Buzz depending on how good your culinary skills are).  Pros:  1. Lots of food  2. Lots of upgrades for your food  3. Hard, Fast & Rewarding  4. Good Art  5. Very Addictive  7. Extra Events a.k.a Challenges that can reward you extra cash but some challenges are way harder to do  8. Random E-mails (Some of them are funny)  9. Good Tutorials  10. You Can Date Other People Who Love Cooking (Not Actual People Just In The Game)  11. Good Music  Cons:  1. I thought the lack of multitasking was an issue for me like for example I'm cooking a burger but I notice some of my other food or chores is going to disappear if I don't interact with it so I try to click on the disappearing object while I'm cooking the burger but nothing happens (Well The only Time I'm able to click on a disappearing object while I'm cooking is if the food is ready to serve), I thought there would be multitasking with the food & chores but I guess not...  2. Every time you do a correct dish for the person your dating they always take up most of your time texting which leaves a lot of angry customers because I'm busy using my cellphone instead of making food (Again this is an issue with no multitasking)  Overall This game always makes me hungry & I highly recommend buying this Yummy Game.
To the people who ordered pizza during my perfect rush hour.    ♥♥♥♥. You.

It looks like a fun, casual, restaurant sim until you try to play it. And then its true form is revealed. Gordon Ramsay as your cheerleader won't even help you. Good luck.   Also all the free stuff that keeps getting added is amazing.

Similar to Diner Dash but utilizes more on keyboard play, this game deals with running a restaurant and strive to restore to it's former glory.   Gameplay (9/10)  This is where the game shines most, getting various interesting food orders from customers that can really test your eye, hand and brain coordination to make sure you don't screw it up and get as many perfect points as you can, managing your menu, buying equipments and upgrading your food quality, random events that can influence the number of customers coming to your restaurant, there's definitely a lot of elements that comes into play. Simple, yet fast packed action.   Graphics (9/10)  Cartoonish graphics is nice here with also nice looking food and it's also nice to see yourself plopping on ingredients onto your own made food ordered by your customers.   Sound/Music (8/10)  Sound wise it's rather simple, nothing mind blowing here but it gets the job done right here. Music wise it is catchy, nice and during certains parts of the game it gets better. The only problem with this is that it can get repetitive but still it suits the game's atmosphere just fine.  Controls (10/10)  The controls are quite simple, fully utilizing the keyboard functions when preparing your customer's food and the best part is you get to customize and configure the settings to your own liking and corresponds to the keys to certaing ingredients (Example: Cheese - C)   Overall (9/10)  Fast, simple and interesting game which has a lot more depth than Diner Dash. Try it out if you're interested for a simple game : )
I tried so hard to fulfill the customer requests in Cook, Serve, Delicious' 'extreme difficulty'.  Now i'm a typist in a supreme court.  10/10.

Thinking about Cook, Serve, Delicious, I wish there was a third option in terms of my recommendation: a sideways thumb. Before I begin, I would like to admit I have a fake food fetish. Wooden toy sushi rolls, plastic hamburgers that can be assembled, lego food. It all stirs my imagination and I often find lingering over these items when I encounter them if out holiday shopping for nieces and nephews. So the premise, setting and aesthetics of most any cooking sim definitely attracts me.  Now on to this game itself:  I've seen CSD described as a 'hardcore cooking/restaurant' sim. It's not though.  The game boils down to an ellaborate typing and algorithm test. The restaurant and cooking simulation gets a bit weird when soup reveals itself to be one of the most complex dishes to prepare in the game, as you are tasked with prepping each order for soup from scratch.  One missed keystroke not only spoils a dish but you are forced to serve the meal to the customer even though you've cuaght the error. There is no option to 'start over' at a hit for time and or money spent on wasted food.  In my mind, a real 1st person hardcore restaurant sim would challenge you to manage time, like choosing to prep veg and make a new pot of soup prior to lunch rushes. To anticipate and use down time strategically between meals. You might even get a sous chef or kitchen hand who can help chop carrots, etc. or maybe you need to send them to the nearest market because your kitchen just ran out of cream or butter (as sometimes happens in the real world!).  It's not that I want a restaurant sim that is as so close to reality that it would fit in with titles such as 'Farming Simulator 2015.' I think an ideal title in this genre could still have the same pace of gameplay that this first iteration of Cook Serve Delicious has, but I would like to see a little more nuance in the structure of the day and the gameplay throughout the day other than a speed challenge to mash buttons with no planning or strategy. For gods' sake, at least make a pot of soup serve 6-10 customers!  Short of it, I think the cooking game genre still has a ways to go. There is room out there for a true 'hardcore cooking & restauarant sim.' But despite it's charms, CSD is not that title for me.  (That being said, I've become something of an achievement hound as of late and I will likely continue to play the game, at least till I hit around 50% completion.)
All the best and worst parts of the food service industry with a sugar coating!! Just like captain crunch only it won't destroy the roof of your mouth.

I'd heard people raving about this game for a little while, but put off getting it because I didn't understand how a restaurant management sim could be so good. I've never been so wrong. Cook, Serve, Delicious is one of the most addictive games I've played in a long time. Every once in a long while a game comes along that just executes every single thing it set out to do, and executes those things perfectly. This is one of those games.  It's a deep game, mechanically speaking. You have access to a large number of different foods, restaurant equipment, and upgrades that can make it easier to manage your customers, prepare your food, or earn the almighty dollar (which in turn lets you buy and upgrade more food, natch). But despite this, the game has one of the softest learning curves I've ever seen, gently letting you flourish from a struggling corn dog cart jockey to a masterful soux chef and maybe even find some love along the way.  The biggest key to the success of CSD has to be it's intuitive nature. Not since Wii Sports have I played a game that has such natural feeling controls. After a few minor stumbles along the way (v for olives, n for onions) I find myself juggling prep stations with ease, pounding out orders quickly, glancing at the minimum info I need and making sure I'm not feeding anyone raw fish, unless they want it.  Finally, the art and sound really seal the deal. The background music keeps things hopping and peaks and ebbs when it needs to, and the distinctive sounds for various events keep you focused on what's important. The perfect 'whoof' that I heard the first time I set something on fire was particularly memorable, but the separate dings for dishes that are ready vs. prepped are essential.  In short, this is a fantastically well put together game that has given me more hours of enjoyment than several 'AAA' titles (that cost me far more, to boot) and I can think of exactly zero reasons that would make me hesitate to recommend this game to anyone. Unless of course you're some kind of fun-hating grump.
I like cooking. It's one of my favorite pastimes, and a great way to unwind. I think it's easy, fun, and a low-stress way to spend an evening.  This game changed my mind.
I was robbed by a man with sexy lips. 10/10
Cook, Serve, Addicted!

This game was probably my favorite game to come out in 2013, and I still love playing it now.  The controller is amazing, can be hard to get used to at the start but when you get that rumble as you're going along, it's just enjoyable.

This is by far one of my favorite games that I own in my Steam Library. When people want to know a lesser known game that I recommend, I recommend this game.   Cook, Serve, Delicious! is a wonderful game that simulates what it would feel like being on a the line for a popular restaurant. You have to cook, you have prepare, you have to serve the food all perfectly or face the consequences. CSD is a restaurant sim, it is a cooking sim, it is the food simulator that we've been waiting for. The gameplay is excellent, the different modes are challening and bring new ways to play the game. If you want to just casually play a few rounds, you can do that, if you want to compete against those around the world, you can do that as well.

This game is amazing! I picked it up during the weekly humble bundle that is going on right now, and it is wonderful. I don't recommend this game for those that have ragile keyboards, but if you want to take the risk of destroying your keyboard and throw it out the window, then go right ahead. You can also use your gamepads (controllers) to replace that, but you might break a button.
Bought this a few days ago after watching a video saying this was a nice game. For $0.99 this is a great deal, I've had a lot of fun with this game

Wow, this game is really cool! I was not at all prepared to be that entertained. The gameplay is really a casual game's gameplay, graphics too, it's repetitive... So I could not understand all these great ratings! Now I do!  The developers did a really good job, because its simple gameplay gets so much addictive: press corresponding keys to take a plate, put some ingredients, cook it, serve... delicious! Funny situations can turn out- distracted by all the dishes to wash, you get confused by the *ding!* of a potato in the oven... and serve a raw pizza to a very angry customer!  I am not done with that game, actually far from it, it feels like I am still at the beginning, it takes time to have a perfect restaurant! And yet I know every time I have ten minutes to kill, I'll try with pleasure to play 2 or 3 days and buy this fryer or this soda dispenser I've been eyeing for weeks!  I do recommend and I look forward to its sequel, such a nice little game deserves more content!
Everyone who uses this restaurant is a dirty animal. 10/10 would force customers to flush the ♥♥♥♥ing toilet themselves if there was the option
Extremely addictive and surprisingly difficult, CSD is like playing WarioWare in career mode. Try the demo from their website if it sounds interesting

Ultimate button-mashing experience, I played a lot of the 'Papa's *insert food related title*' flash games online so this was naturally right up my alley. I feel that I have gotten plenty of playtime out of this game and I'm just now finishing up the last achievement after 55 hours which may not seem that high but you can only button mash for so long after you've reached a platinum level restaurant :)   Definitely recommend!
I used to work in the kitchen. This was more stressful.
As a restaurant worker I can tell you first hand that there are not enough people asking if everything is gluten free, 9/10

Fun and surprisingly addicted keyboard mashing cooking game. Progression can be a timesink but still very enjoyable, and there is definitely a feeling of the game getting more and more difficult as you continue.

This game starts out incredibly difficult and almost detered me from deciding to play it more than a few times, but once I got the hang of it and leanred what foods I'm good at preparing, it's incredibly fun! Of course, this game certainly won't appeal to many people. The concept of 'Run your restaraunt from the ground up' isn't exactly a very new genre; it's a genre that has been used and adapted by many for ages. Nevertheless, the playstyle is unlike anything else I have played before, and the art, music, and suprising amount of subtle humor is what kept me coming back. I'd reccomend giving it a shot- you just may love it!
Can't stop playing. It's like Kitchen Dash on crack.

Game is super fun and fast paced. Everything I want out of a casual game. I can sit down before work, play a day and then i'm out the door. and when I have the day off, i will play it for hours. The difficulty is actually my favorite part. It doesn't stay static like some games but continues to get even more difficult. I even feel guilty when I mess up an order. The challenge system is fun and interesting and (again) challenging! best part about it is that the achivements aren't impossible either. 10/10 will continue to play over and over again

Good game I had been wanting for a while. The only thing I dont like was the look on homies face when I didnt instantly have a pretzel for him. SORRY YOU HAD TO WAIT TWO SECONDS! Go find another burger joint, jerk.

You will know the true meaning of pain when, while desperately trying to time the baked potatoes you are cooking so they all go off at slightly different times so as to not swamp you, you accidentally pound merely FIVE times into that chicken, and that woman gives you a look of contempt as she walks away, disgusted with her merely mostly tenderized bit of meat.

You're an employer, looking to hire new people, and a candidate is telling you they're flexible, a fast learner and good at handling stress? Let them have a go at this game and find out if any of it is true.
....Wow, You're literally the only worker at a restaurant, it's frantic, and it's great. it's like those games on newgrounds but way better.

A clever cross between a typing game (Typing of the Dead, etc.) and a business management simulator. It's fun, engaging, and keeps you coming back for that perfect day that always seem just out of reach.
A non-violent and challenging little game, that demands quick fingers with memory coordination. Perfect for passing intense whiles but for a short period of time.

I just want to say this game looks AMAZINGLY fun. Reminds me of that Spongebob Lights Camera Pants minigame from my childhood. Unfortuately, as of right now, the Linux (Ubuntu at least) version has issues with gamepads. My Logitech F310 works for any other game I own, but not this one. The game DOES recognize it, but doesn't respond to any button presses. Until they fix it, I'm afraid I have to say stay away. The developer(s) seems very helpful in the forums, but have not found a solution yet.
Awesome hand eye coordination game! What a challenging restaurant business game should be like. I hope they add more features and items in the future.  10/10

While appearing to be a food service simulator, Cook, Serve, Delicious feels more like a mini-game compilation in the vein of WarioWare. You are in charge of single-handed running the busiest restaurant in the world, and are expected to prepare and serve each meal promptly and to order. This is simple with cheaper dishes such as corn dogs and fish filet; however, as the game progresses, and you are asked to prepare more complicated meals, the pace mounts exponentially. Balancing your menu not only involved making sure you don't serve the same thing too often: it also involves balancing your menu so that you don't serve too many difficult dishes at once. For those not satisfied with the normal progression, random bets and Steam challenges are here to give you the opportunity to grab extra bragging rights.  Honestly, CSD is one of the best cooking games I've played, and it's definitely worth the full $10.
Brought this game for peanuts in the last steam sale and have to say it's been my best impulse buy ever! So addictive. A really fun little game, would definitely recommend.
This game is super simple to understand and play..yet soooooo addicting! It becomes faster paced as you play, and yes, still requires some thought! Two thumbs up!

One of those weird little games based entirely in repetition that is almost inexplicably addictive and enjoyable. The artstyle is appealing, the UI simple and fitting, and the controls fairly intuitive. Has a hidden depth and complexity to it that I hadn't expected. I could easily see myself losing hours to this game.

The game is awesome, at the first look you can think it's just a browser game on Steam, but when you start playing it turns really addicting! The game brings a big challenge, you need to serve your customers while you do simple chores like wash dishes and throw the trash out, and awkward chores like flushing the toilet (apaprently the customers can't do it) and fending off robbers. Some recipes, you just need to press a key or two, but for others you need lots of ingredients, and every upgrade adds more ingredients, turning the game really challenging. The game also have an enjoyable atmosphere, with good music and simple, but still pretty graphics. The only bad things about the game are the low variety of recipe, the slow progression of stars, and we should be able to change our restaurant's appearence, it only changes when we get a new star. The game is simple, but still addicting, great for fans of this kind of games, and have a good atmosphere for new players in this kind of game. 7.5/10

You get lots of orders at a time, only to find yourself under pressure to cook all of them exactly right and serve them in time. On top of that, there's (almost) always chores to make: doing the dishes, taking out the garbage, setting up rat traps... not that fancy, is it? And still, when you manage to do everything just fine, it feels SO satisfying! The game manages to keep that tension up most of the time, making you feel that you're just one step away from screwing up your combo -because, after all, you are-, and yet it always seems to be a manageable challenge. It's just exhilarating to get everything right!  On top of that, the atmosphere is sublime - the graphics are cute, and all the music and sounds fit together perfectly. There's nothing that feels out of place in here - the attention to detail is exquisite.

I am about 5 hours in to this game and it is very addicting! By giving the player a chance to own their own restaurant...Cook, Serve, Delicious gives players a unique culinary experience from their PC. I like the controller support and the gameplay is very fast paced. I work in a kitchen in real life and this game somehow keeps me interested after a long shift at work. I am going to be the best chef ever, damnit!  for now I give it a solid 7/10.   ALLEZ CUISINE!

Cook, Serve, Delicious! is the pinnacle of restaurant 'simulator' games. Not only do you manage your own restaurant, but you micro manage every aspect of it. From changing your menu daily, to upgrading your kitchen, to competing in challenges, to reading emails and taking bets, to purchasing new foods and upgrading them, this game is incredibly detailed. The art and music are a bit simple but it fits the theme of the game pretty well. Gameplay is mostly muscle memory with key presses, so I would recommend watching gameplay before purchasing. It's not for everyone, but if you love a good typing challenge while trying to earn five stars on your restaurant, this game is for you. Lobster is OP.

I saw this game on the new releases & said out loud 'that looks like a silly game'. Curious I went to the forums, read over a few thread & ended up watching a half hour video from Giant Bomb. I then bought the game. The first thing you'll hear about the game is that it is hard & hectic. At first it did appear to live up to that. After a couple of hours playing I got the hang of it & the challenge started to fade. When I got to a 1 star restaurant, the game decided to come back & destroy my happy little life. Cook, Serve, Delicious! is a very fun, challenging game. Highly recommended.
This should be an eSport.
I have a salad bar that specialises in beer and burgers... 10/10
lovely cooking sim absolutely sound
A customer ordered a medium drink and I gave him a large! I GAVE HIM A LARGE! I've soiled the good CSD name!  SOILED IT! SOILED IT! SOILED IT! SOILED IT!

Recommended for people who lost their jobs as border security officers in glorious People's Republic of Arstotzka.  If you are seeking opportunities in culinary gameplay and can mentally shift gears to cook different dishes, this will test your focus.   4 stars! -Yelp!

This, this game. Holy hell. It's just amazing. It's a perfect marriage of Wario Ware, Cooking Mama, and dating sims. It has a high level of mastery, as well as the coveted 'just one more round' feeling. It's wonderful and worth it at $10, hell, they could get away with $15 easy. Great Dev, great game, just support them.

I've been a fan of Vertigo Games for a long while now, ever since playing their 'Ore No Ryomi' game, so it really was not much of a surprise that Mr. Chubigans (founder and primary designer) was planning on making a sequel.  The game itself borrows heavily from the PS1 game 'Ore No Ryouri' in that it is essentially a simulator of running a restaurant entirely by yourself. No waitstaff, no chef, just you, a kitchen, and a counter full of customers. The game itself is played entirely with the keyboard, selecting first the customer/ticket you wish to service, then hitting the correct keys to process the order correctly.  The controls do get a little frustrating at times, but it appears that Mr. Chubigans has added a key binding menu for each dish, so any you have particular trouble with can now be changed. Also, the graphics are impeccably watercolor style, and the music/sound design make this game far more relaxing than you would expect from the time-management genre. Highly recommended for the price!

Very cool game in the vein of Papers,Please. In many aspects even better, except for the story maybe. Gameplay makes up for it though - more engaging and entertaining. If you always dreamed about a job in fast food restaurant but life took you elsewhere, this is your chance!
This game is superb, an advanced diner dash/tapper. Starts off easy but has loads and loads of expansion and additions and soon becomes frantic fun. Highly recommended.
Omg it's AMAZING, it looks real boring, but Geez! it's so addictive!

Got it from the Humble Simulator Bundle 2. What should I say? An addictive game! I don't know what is with it, but I'm telling you: amazing. The soundtrack never gets boring as it's really well made and entertaining. Everything is 10/10 except sometimes if you try to let's say filet the fish (press right, down, left) really quickly it doesn't recognize one of the buttons so you end up giving the guy a fish filet with the tail still on or something, which leads to an average or a bad order. So my final verdict is...9/10, an addictive game!
Fun Game Had a lot of work and thought put in to it ,

A fast paced game that is really fun game where you choose your foods and make them yourself while cleaning the dishes, throwing out the trash, setting mice trap and more! You have a checklist to become a higher star resturant, get special events, upgrade food and practice them until perfection! Its a fun game as said before.

When messing around on Game Maker, I found a game called 'Ore No Ryomi 2 - The Restaurant' on their community. This was probably the most addictive and fun food-related game I've played. It requires that you have fast fingers, a good memory and technique. This updated, paid version of the game was an absolute shock to me when I saw it on Steam, and it is definitely something I would recommend to someone who wants a simple yet fast-paced game!
♥♥♥♥in' hate this xD
Love love love this game! You get to play as a line cook, partake in different menu challenges and claw your way up to a five star restaurant.

I just love this game, it reminds me of those flash games I used to play as a kid and also a little bit of the Burguer Shop series. But even more evolved because you have a ton of things to upgrade in your restaurant, recepies, services, menu etc. And even the chores like taking out the trash, cleaning dishes and flushing the toilet are your responsability. Sometimes kind of infuriating but in a totally awesome way. 10/10 would recommend.
Cook, Burn, Swear.  (Also really great way to learn your keyboard)

A fun little game, perfect for killing time. The graphics and music (jazz variety) are great. Wish there were more contents, but I've been told by the developers they're moving onto the next project :( Still, really enjoyable and would recommend to restaurant management sim fans.
It's more of a diner dash except you don't have to sit people you have to clean the toilet, take the trash out, etc. I recommend if you like something like that.

After breaking my keyboard several times while playing Ore no Ryomi, seeing this game on Steam with tears in my eyes is priceless.  Nice work Vertigo Gaming. Great job.   *cries more*  10/10 would break arrow keys while chasing thiefs again  only real fans can understand..  *more tear*

A cooking and restaurant simulator were you press a bunch of keys/buttons as fast as possible in order to satisfy your customers.     Pros   Addicting gameplay   A lot of food to choose for your menu   Tons of upgrades (Restaurant and Food) that changes the format of button pressing.   Challenges/Tournaments   Local-Co op    Great replay-value      Con   At times, a few of the food choices are difficult to pull of if you put it in your 'Daily Special' slot like SOUP and PASTA >.<. ( NOTE :  I played with Keyboard, so it might be easier with a controller ).   This is probably one of my favorite games here on Steam. I highly reccomend it if you are into these types of games. I definitely will continue to play this game for its challenges and being the 'World's Best Restaurant.'

At first, I wasn't expecting much out of this game when I first laid my eyes on it, simply due to not being interested in these kinds of games in general. However, after getting this in a humble bundle, I gave it a shot and man is this a blast. It is literaly just a series of glorified quick-time event, but it's actually entertaining rather than in most other games that actually makes it annoying to go through. The goal of Cook, Serve, Delicious is work your way up from a zero star restaurant all the way up to a five star restaurant and is it very satisfiying to perfectly serve all of your customers at the end of the day. My only regret is that I wish I wasn't being such a cheapskate when paying for my humble bundle. Ah who am I kidding? I do this almost everytime I buy a game.
This is a best time-management/typing simulator/tycoon/food simulation game I've played in my whole life. Absolutely the best. 10/10

fun, Fun, FUN!  I love Cook, Serve, Delicious. It's fun, it's humorous and it's so relaxing to play!  CSD is a game based on a simple concept. You have a restaurant, you make a menu and at any moment you can have customers coming in for some variety of food you have put on your menu. Cooking requires typing correctly in a sequence to prepare your food and serve it.  There are a lot of additional factors to 'spice up' the gameplay, like Rush Hours (two per day, lunch and dinner, a lot of customers come in at the same time), VIPs (they want to eat specific things), Robberies (you need to help the police identify the criminal), Romance (people who love specific things you cook), the Iron Cook challenge (Iron Chef spoof, you have to cook extremely fast), the Hunger Festivities (you have to cook perfectly ALL varieties of a certain food item in a sequence), Bets (you are challenged to have a specific menu) and a few other things here and there which I'm surely forgetting.  All in all, totally worth your money.

These restaurant-managing sims are a guilty pleasure of mine, and I think this one will keep that part of my brain satisfied indefinitely. Smoothly polished gameplay, good variety of items to make (all with their own quirks; like having to fry or chop ingredients, and whether you cook at the start, middle, or end of preparation), and a decent amount of fluff around the edges to round out the game. Also it actually gets seriously challenging.  You know how these games work; if not go google 'Papa's Burgeria', play for ten minutes, and then come back. It is a big pile of minigames, and you go through a game-day worth of them at a time.  * Includes non-food chores (dishes, trash, etc) that carry special penalties if you fail them * Health inspections, which make the chores harder for a game day * Optional dating minigame; where a special customer shows up, and if you do well on their order they'll text you during work (reading comprehension time trial) * Optional betting minigames, where you take on extra challenges to make more income in a day * At-your-liesure speed/accuracy trials, guised as catering jobs, iron chef competitions, and something hilarious * Upgrade your recipes and restaurant over time, adding new complexities to recipes * Weekly leaderboard challenges * Amusing tidbits to read (fake spam emails, food and event descriptions)

Memorize how to maximize the efficiency of your recipes and other restaurant owning responsibilities to make the most out of every single day. This game is a great risk/reward arcade-style time management/button mashing game that is definitely worth your time.  This game is good. Real good.

You play as a line cook who also has to keep up with chores while completeing orders. It sounds overwhelming, and at first it is but eventually you adapt to the gameplay. This is honestly one of the most fun and interesting games I've played in a while. So many little things come together to make it feel fantastic. The aesthetic design is great. The visuals are interesting and varied without being overwhelming, and the sound effects when preparing food make it so satisfying. The soundtrack is also great, and it perfectly fits the tone of the game. There's jazz, funk, samba, all sorts of styles, and all of them can be either driving or relaxing.The game is also well balanced, which may seem like a weird thing to say, but there was never one setup that I knew I could coast through the whole game with. The game makes you change up your menu and buy and upgrade your foods to make it more varied and challenging. And boy, does it get challenging. But it never punishes you for some bs reason. If you get punished, it's because you made a mistake. And since you can arrange your own menu, you only make it as difficult as you want to. Most of the time, anyways. This game is so fantastic, and I cannot praise it highly enough. It may be one of my favorite games. You may not have the same experience as I did, but I would still highly reccommend that you at least try out this game. At $10, it's a great buy.

From the sheer volume of words written about it in the Storefront I was expecting something like an updated Pizza Tycoon but instead it's basically Diner Dash, just with menu-driven QTEs instead of the maze-platforming. I guess 'videogame 'journalists'' will get all tl;dr about p.much anything.  How the game actually goes: Press key to take order. Press keys to make order. Press key to serve order. Sometimes you have to take out the trash or wash dishes or flush a toilet, and you do these things by pressing keys. Rinse. Repeat. After a day is over you can buy new dishes (click dish, click purchase), buy new equipment (the only reason you'll do this is to unlock different dishes or automate some of the trash-taking dish-washing toilet-flushing), or add things to make people wait longer before exiting in a huff. You buy new equipment by clicking on it, btw. Oh but wait, that's not all, you can also plan your menus! (by clicking the foods you've bought)  The 'menu-planning' is kinda simplistic (some dishes get 'old' after two consecutive days, that's really the only thing preventing you from keeping a static min-maxed menu of the Highest Priced Items), and the 'upgrades' are only necessary from an achievement-farming / restaurant star rating upgrade perspective, generally you have to serve 200-300 of a dish before you even recoup the initial investment. To put that in perspective, each day you can expect to sell a maximum of about 50 total dishes across all types.  It's a fun distraction and the execution is great for what it is (you can even rebind the QTE keys - major props for that) but on the other hand the 'upgrade your restaurant' progression requires twenty game-days and after eight game-days it was getting a little tedious so whatever. If Indie, Casual is your thing then by all means check this out, but this isn't a fu­ckin 'Simulation' by any stretch of the imagination and the 'Strategy' is simplistic at best.  If it was categorized properly (Indie, Casual) I'd give it a thumbs-up, but the miscategorization/misrepresentation is pretty sleazy. If this is a strategy simulation then TF2 is a wargame.

In Cook, Serve, Delicious; you are the manager/short order chef/dishwasher/Charlie Day of a walk up restaurant in an office building. You get to select the menu each day and work your way up from a one star to platinum five-star restaurant by meeting certain targets. You can buy and upgrade the foods you put on the menu and as your restaurant progresses more of the luxury foods become available and some of the basic foods become unavailable. For example you can't buy lobster in a one-star restaurant, and sadly can't serve a corndog in a five-star restaurant. You prepare the foods through one or more phases of keystrokes modified by the specific orders desired by the customers. in multiple phase recipes there are interstitial periods of cooking for a certain amount of time, if you exceed the amount of time for cooking a food you may burn it or it may go bad from being held too long. Additional time restrictions come from the customers only waiting a certain amount of time for you to start their order; and the need to take care of chores such as doing the dishes, taking out the trash, and setting mouse traps. In it's essence it's a typing game, with a lot of short term time management. If you don't touch type you'll probably have a tough time in the later game. When you are getting through a lunch rush and moving from order to order though, it ends up feeling more like a rhythm game. I found it highly engaging and to perform well you have to focus very intently in much the same way needed in playing a bullet hell shoot-em up. The game has recently added multi-player functionality and online leader-board challenges, but having only played the single player campaign I can't speak to how good those features are. When I saw this game initially I thought it fun, but it ended up being way more entertaining and engrossing than I expected. I'd give it a 9/10 and a definite recommendation.

Very fast paced and somewhat difficult as it relies on quickly figuring out what to do (as orders change from customer to customer) and then using the right ingredients.  Only problems I have is that I felt like it is overcomplicating a game that is meant to be simple by adding variables to what food you can serve depending on variables such as if it's a fatty food, creates a lot of dishes etc. The first game was quite simple in this regard. Also removed the morning paper from each day which was pretty funny to read in the first game.  As you need to make very quick decisions and know the hotkeys to place the ingredients, it's very important that the game can properly convey this at a glance. Unfortunately it does this a bit worse than the original game but it should be fine if you spend awhile to adjust.  Overall a good game to play for awhile. Pros: + satisfying sound effect + nice music + simple hectic fun touch-typing gameplay + challenge mode + local co-op  Cons: - too much 'up' and 'down' parameter for every food - I wish the bind key marked in ingredient as a capital letter - 20 days to go to first star is kinda a little dragging  Cook, Serve, Delicious is a simple and weird game. The game has excellent sound design. As you perform an action in the game, whether it is changing the size of your fountain drink cup or throwing meat onto the hot grill, there is a pleasurable sound that follows. The game appears pretty simple, but actually has some depth. Each food has certain positives and negatives that you have to take into account when you plan your daily menu. A certain number of foods might be optimal in terms of profitability, and you may be tempted to include only those because you need cash, but I enjoy mastering as many foods as I own as possible. There are various other challenges, such as catering, which may require you to serve certain foods you might not be used to. Catering is a good idea, because you can make more money faster than you can in your restaurant.   Each type of food also carries certain chores with it, which you also must do to maintain your perfect combos. The health inspector shows up every once in awhile to make sure you are doing all your chores. There is equipment that allows you to expand the foods you can cook, mitigate negatives from food you're serving, and make your chores easier. Lately I've been more into games like this, where the goals are clear, but you have some freedom in how you achieve those goals.   The main negative of this game is that it is repetitive and fairly demanding in terms of optimal gameplay. It's difficult to play over a long period of time, because you really need to pay attention to what you're doing. During a rush hour, you really have to keep track of which order has come in first & understand which tasks you should tackle first. You need to take cook times, length of chores, and customer patience into account. When I started having trouble with my health inspections, I first invested in an automatic dishwasher to mitigate my dish washing, which was my most time-consuming chore. After trash became the longest & most troublesome, I got the trash service. The game is very addictive, and because it can be demanding, ti is difficult to play for long periods of time. Sometimes you just have to put the pipe down and detox for awhile.

This game seems on the surface to be a casual cooking/managment game that you often find on free online games websites. This is a cooking game, and a management game, but it is quite debateable whether or not it is 'casual', although I am not saying all casual games are bad, as I have played some good ones, but it does seem to not have as many fatures as a casual game, as cooking and casual aren't always the same thing.  The reason I say this isn't a casual game, is because when you think of casual games, you would normally think of a relaxing and easy-to-play game, something where you don't need to think. This game is far from relaxing, it is a great simulation of having a panic attack. There is no easy mode, only normal and extreme, and even normal mode can seem quite impossible. Juggling all these different foods, while at the same time having to do chores, such as flush the toilet, because we all know that's a chef's job.  The gameplay in this is not only intense, but it is also centred around typing. It would be easy if it was simply typing out words, such as what the food/recipe was, but no, you have to prapere the food, and each ingrediant/action is one letter, meaning you will end up muttering to yourself while you type a ridiculous combo of letters and numbers.   PSCR PSCR PSCR  Once you get use to one combonation of letters for a certain meal, you will then, upgrade it as you go, and struggle to learn even more keys. As well as prapering foods for consumtion, you need to amke sure they don't burn, that you don't accidentally press 4 when you meant to press 5 and serve the food undercooked.  There is so much more to be said about this game: the graphics, the music, the humour and references, the progression, the events, etc. But all that needs to be said for it, is that you should buy it and play it, as it is quite worth it's money, and is a very enjoyable game, with a very high replay value.

Cook, Serve, Delicious!  I originally picked this game up from the Humble GameMaker Bundle, and honestly, I kind of ignored it for a bit. But one day when I was bored I had a go at CSD, and it actually is a great casual game. I personally found the learning curve easy, meaning I've progressed a fair bit in it without sinking huge amounts of time into it. The days can be long, and it can sometimes turn into a grind, but the game rewards you.  Pros:  - Challenging gameplay, but if you learn all of the keys and their functions, you'll be fine. - Easy learning curve, but hard to master.  Cons:  - Can seem like a bit of a grind at times, but I think part of that's just me. - Rush hours are slightly hectic, but that also is mostly me I think.  Overall, I would recommend this game to anyone who was thinking of getting it, as it provides hours of replay ability, and heaps of different pathways through the game.  ~ burgs.exe

150 Megabytes ago, a corporate tower's fantasy became a reality in a forum never seen before: Cook, Serve, Delicious! the restaurant/game. The motivation for spending their fortune to create Cook, Serve, Delicious! was to encounter new original cuisines which could be called true artistic creations. To realize their dream, they secretly started choosing the top chef of various styles of cooking, and they named their man Player 1: the invincible man of culinary skills. Cook, Serve, Delicious! is the arena where the Player awaits the challenges of picky customers from around the building. Using all their senses, skill, luck, they are to prepare artistic dishes from the recipe cards. Every day, stress levels are on the line in Cook, Serve, Delicious!, where the Player pits their artistic creations against the masses. What demands do today's customers bring? And how will the Player fight back? The heat will be on!  Allez Cuisine! (Buy this Game)

This is more like the best cooking game of all time - Order Up for the Wii. It's more Restaurant play - cleaning up, putting together pre-made ingredients, deciding which dishes to buy & which to upgrade, and personalizing per the order. Order Up on the Wii was a magnificent game, and this builds on that idea by making it keyboard-friendly, thus MUCH faster.  Side note - my daughter & her friend streamed this on twitch & loved yelling at the customers. They were able to split between arrow-keys/mouse for one player and 1/2/3/4 & S for the other.. it was a fun vision of teamwork that I found myself missing when I played alone.

To begin this review, I have seen a blog post from this indie developer before it was even on greenlight, and have played the demo on Desura, so you can imagine the happy surprise I had when I saw it on steam! This game is really fun. Fun truly is the best to explain what I felt during it. The sounds of the game truly support the aesthetic of 'Slap the ingredients in the sandwich, you got 50 other things to do!', and the hectic environment it creates supports that. Also, the game challenges you to step out of your comfort zone, which I rarely do. Proof of that is when I had a routine of having beer, salad, ice cream, coffee, and I alternated burgers and pizza (due to menu rot, where people dislike it when certain items stay on the menu for too long.). I was so good at making those that I never failed an order, or got it average. However, the game goes to great lengths to keep itself fresh, in many ways that I cannot describe. Soon enough, I had replaced my entire menu, and having more fun from doing it! I am so happy that Cook, Serve, Delicious was greenlighted!

A deceptively amazing title, this seems like it would be similar to the management aspect of Diner Dash, and the preparatory aspect of Cooking Mama. However, structure it all in the fast-paced microgame style of WarioWare, and Cook, Serve, Delicious comes up as an absolute joy. My only major criticism is the lengthy amount of time it takes to advance one star, but with the content on offer, it works well with the game's relentlessly addictive nature. If you're looking for something that's not too challenging on the surface, this isn't a bad choice, although be warned that it gets rather hectic depending on the volume of customers and what you've chosen for your day's menu.

I am a fan of simulation games, and I have been playing my share of them. This game can be one of the better ones that I have played.  I can come in from both sides of the argument here and say that, this game is basically nothing but memorizing what you need to do, and how to do it. It's nothing more than pressing the correct button at the correct time, so that the correct thing hapens.  ...but I have to argue, there's something with how it is presented, something that just lures me to play more and more of this game, it's simple, it's pushing correct buttons at correct timing, but... it is packaged in a way that you won't really get bored while playing it. The rewards are rewarding and somewhat on time. You won't get almost everything in one sitting, you have to gradually adapt, to see, which menus do you like (read: not screw up) the most, which menus needed to be changed daily, which menus do give a positive vibe and thus rack in more customers, etc. It's a nice little sugar on top of the icing to make the game more interactive and press the players to learn newer foods and their preparation.  All in all, for the price the game is worth, it's worth buying, I'd strongly reccomend this game.

Cook, Serve, Delicious! is, at its heart, a mashup of Cooking Mama and Diner Dash, but it replaces the casual game trappings with more difficult challenges to complete and with more going on with the underlying (basic) economic simulator. The cooking minigames are mostly easier than what you'd find in Cooking Mama, and this allows them to be completed quickly, which is essential to surviving the lunch/dinner rush. The result is a game that while resembling the aforementioned games with a dash of Wario Ware thrown in for seasoning, ends up somehow being better than the sum of its parts. Recommended.

Awesome Game, one thing is missing and that is Gordon Ramsey yelling that you're f***ing pathetic!!

Oddly enough, I run restaurants for a living in real life. I found this game, and now I run restaurants non-stop! Lessons from the game to life to the game to the life to the game of life. It is an endless rush hour. I can not, and have not, stopped playing this game! (The music rocks, as well)
It's food... what else do you need... apart from food yourself while playing
Overall: 4 out of 5
Wasn't expecting it to be so much fun and addictive

'Cook, Serve, Delicious!' is restaurant-simulation casual game where you get to made a variety of delicious foods to serve your customers, manage and upgrade your restaurant to become 5 stars! It's the most fun casual game I have played. I highly recommend it if you are looking for a casual game to play and have fun.

I've had this game for awhile now and i have to say it really blew me away on well it was designed and just how much fun it is to play, i have always loved cooking games but most of them arent really much of a challenge and more focus on being relaxing, fun little games, that all changed when i downloaded Cook, Serve, Delicious! From the start it was a learning prosesss to manage your costomers, menu, and chores all while having to cook good tasting food, at first i kept having really bad days until i started learning to play smart, choosing items that are easy to make quickly while stillmaking a good amount of money and learning new foods one at a time, once i did that i was hooked on the game, its so much fun to progress your resturant and unlock new foods and equipment to help make things a bit easier on your self, the weekly challenges are great fun as well as the iron cook and catering. The only thing i think should be worked on and i know it wouold kinda take away from the challenage as time gos on is that was a five star resturant you should have at least one employee to do the chores FOR you instead of you handling them all the time like you did as a 1 start place, other then that i love the game and i think anyone who loves cooking games should give it a try, warn you though, might take some getting used to before you start making good food.
An easy game to get sucked into; the best, most customizable restaurant sim around
Nice fun game to pass the time. Gets a bit repetitive though as you grind for more cash to buy more recipes. Still worth playing though.
Loved it! This game just sucks me in and before I know it I can't stop. It's hell but I love it!

10/10 Fast-Food-Restaurant-Employee-Simulator  + Very Original game and character design + Detailed variety of foods and menues  + Online competitions  - The game needs tons of time and patience to be finished  - Pretty slow progress - Monotone after a while of playing   For 9,99€ the game is a little too boring - maybe only usable for casual gaming. But if you find it on sale, I would definitely recommend.
Addictive fun game which make you more appreciate foods you've bought.
one of the best typing game you'll ever had
You are the sole owner, chef, cashier, janitor, dish washer, exterminator, bartender, security guard, and waiter for a fast food restaurant that serves lobster.
Addictive and amazing. Currently going through my second playthrough!

If you need a 'time killer' type of a game, this is it!  You shouldn't expect much of a tycoon or a business game here, because this is definitely not one. However, there's a minimal amount of 'economy' which you should take care. This is actually a reflex-action game, where you are successful if your hand-eye coordination if good.   I'm playing this game whenever I have long trips or waiting somewhere; doesn't need internet and much of a PC resource which means you can play for hours on power-saving mode :)  I can't 'strongly' recommend the game however if you need a time killer, that's a good choice.
Starts out reasonably slow but turns into a surprisingly funny and intense game. Challenging but easy to learn.
Playing a cooking game while smashing keys, perfect pastime.  11/10 would mash keys.
Surprisingly fun despite seemingly easy to begin with.
Definitely better with a gamepad, but this game is a pretty fun little time waster/management game. Well worth it if you can get it like I did in a bundle for cheap. 8/10
The game is great, but I would like a online multiplayer in this game, I would recommend this game.
Fun game, makes you hungry. Asmany have said easy to pick up hard to master. Reallllly hungry.
This game is easy to learn and hard to master, but when you have mastered it you feel like you are the best at it

The best time management/cooking simulator game I've ever played. Big sort of recipes, achievements, goals, and challenges. Lovely graphics, easily rememberable and logical button mapping. Sometimes I play one session for hours, and I just don't notice it. The music matches the atmosphere, awesome soundtrack! Congrats for the developers! Challenging. Addictive. Variable. Original. Fantastic! This is Cook, Serve, Delicious!
Expert at every option in the game but beer. How hard is it to hold the down button for a mere second yet overfill it every time? Ask this girl...
Didn't need to finish culinary school because I had this game. Now I can cook anything and everything. Play this game if you want to learn how to cook.

nothing really new or special but it's addictive, it's a kind of cooking mama but with more pathos for some bets and troubles.  Maybe 9,99 euro is too much, my boyfriend bouht it during steam sales and the price he paid was ok (about 4 euro). give it a chance!
Extremely hectic, extremely addicting.
It's fun, addictive, and as hard as you want it to be. And you can't go wrong with the soundtrack either.
Incredibly addictive!

I got this just because it was cheap at first, I eneded up spending a lot of time in it. It is actually rather addictive. I really enjoy it.
This game has taken many hours of my life, and now I'm waiting for the second game to come out. Before that happens, I'll make my resturaunt world famous.

fast paced arcade-y game that becomes stale the later you get on in levels. there's nothing to bring people back except muh stars. there's no sense of reward, gameplay wise. you're told you're gold star and you get more foods to cook but that's it, i expected more. still worth the purchase. the art is really funny.

I usually like those kind of games and seriously, this one is worth every cent I put in it (even though I bought it in sale, hehe). I saw 'hardcore' and decided this was for me a call for challenge.  The beginning is fairly easy (okay, I freaked out and rage-quitted during the first rush hour), and gets gradually more and more difficult.  I thought 30 foods wouldn't be enough to keep me busy, but with the upgrades, there actually are a good number of recipe to unlock. I hope you have a good memory...   Achieving a perfect day makes me feel like I'm an awesome keyboard smasher warrior cook.  Graphisms are pretty, game easy to handle but hard to master  I would definitly recommend and am patiently (not so much) waiting for the second one!  P.S. : I was stupid enough to try hardcore mode. I don't know how I'm still alive.
